body: I think there's nothing wrong, but maybe it's worth throwing a specialized runtime exception rather than a generic GdxRuntimeException.
@davebaol any chance you could make this code path more robust? I feel very uncomfortable with the markup parser just crashing on invalid input.

I think that's a good idea, considering it can be reused to check and
potentially throw a proper exception in other places.

I vote for optional. override setMarkupEnabled to have a second parameter which decides whether to throw an exception or silently ignore wrong colors. IMO throwing exceptions should be default.

I'd lean toward not throwing an exception, just render the invalid markup without changing colors. After all, invalid markup is just text. What is the use case for wanting to know the markup is invalid?

During development I'd like to be notified if I made a typo and the color code doesn't exist. I can't speak for others but I don't usually check each and every string for correctness, especially when it comes to translations from i18n files.

An exception is only marginally better, since you still have to get the app
into a state where it renders the problematic text. The exception only
saves you from having to note the error visually. Would it be better to
have markup validation that could be run on all the strings? Then you would
know up front if there are issues.

Maybe the optional exception is ok too, it's just a relatively uncommon
approach that makes me feel like there might be a better alternative.

I think it should silently remove the bad markups. But maybe some option to throw an exception if you want to. Anyways, I would just like to say thank you everyone for supporting my suggetion. I thought it would be a nice idea and it seems that peope agree! By the way, to the LibGDX devs, take your time adding this, its no rush for me right now.

I would say you shouldn't "remove" bad markup - just don't crash, and
display it as normal text.

Even better, for me at least, keep the bad markup in the text just make it have no effect. So no exceptions thrown and if a bad markup is there, it is easy to debug and tell where the markup is bad. If you need an example of what I mean just ask.

Done!
Now unknown markup colors are silently ignored and considered as normal text.
